s.text: Gels were stained with ethidium bromide and viewed using a UV trans-illuminator.
The majority of PCR products were sequenced using dye-terminator chemistry (ABI Prism FS, PE Applied Biosystems, Boston, MA).
This method was chosen to detect sequences with potential similarity to pXO2 because it is rapid and the reaction products can be readily sequenced.

Although the region is not bracketed by IS elements or tRNAs that are characteristic of pathogenicity islands (PAIs), it bears features that are similar to the putative PAI identified in the B. anthracis plasmid pXO1 [ 20 ] . Bacterial sequences with similarity to the B. anthracis cap genes are present in sequence databases.
Conservation of plasmid sequences can provide clues about the origin of the pXO2 plasmid and about potentially conserved gene functions.
These ORFs have sequence similarity to a conserved hypothetical protein found in several bacterial genera and the tetR family of transcriptional repressors, respectively.
The only pXO2 ORFs found in common with the isolates most closely related to B. anthracis (Jaccard distance of 0.55 or less) were ORFs 47 and 48.
3 kb cap gene-containing region, which appeared to be unique to B. anthracis .
